item.question:
Which of the following commands will do the same as kill -s INT 3022.
Select all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will set the the default permissions for new files to <font face="monospace">rw-r-----</font>, regardless of the current setting?
item.hint: Beware that using the numeric notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should block. Using the symbolic notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should let through.

item.question:
You want to know how much disk-space you are using in your homedirectory.
Which of the following commands will accomplish this?
item.hint: The question does not state what your current working directory is. Hence, the remark that you want to know the disk-space in your homedirectory allows you to easily eliminate to possible answers.

item.question: How do you remove 2 complete lines (the current one and the one below the cursor) in the <font face="monospace">vi</font>-editor?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command is used to change the owner of a particular file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What best describes the above commandline when executed?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
<font face="monospace">cat</font> reads the files <font face="monospace"><</font> and <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> and sends the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
No output as <font face="monospace">guru1</font> is not a valid username
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font>-signal to the webserver-process <font face="monospace">httpd</font> (process id 2384) causing it to re-read its configuration?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can display the free inodes for all mounted file systems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.exhibit:
$ ls -l foo bar
lrwxrwxrwx 1 guru1 course 3 Aug 31 14:12 bar -> foo
-rw-r--r-- 1 guru1 course 10 Aug 31 14:12 foo
$ rm bar
item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
As you can see bar is a symbolic link, pointing to foo.
As user guru1 you execute 'rm bar'.
What happens?
item.choice: Nothing, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> is no ordinary file.
Both <font face="monospace">foo</font> and <font face="monospace">bar</font> would be removed.
Only <font face="monospace">foo</font> would be removed, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> points to <font face="monospace">foo</font>.
You would be asked whether <font face="monospace">bar</font> or <font face="monospace">foo</font> should be removed.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file/directory usually has a sticky bit?
item.choice: Every file that needs to stay memory-resident.
item.hint: When the question mentions something in general you must assume how things are done in Debian or RedHat system or specified in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.

item.question:
According to the File Hierarchy Standard some directories are mandatory on the root-filesystem.
Which of the following directories should reside on the root-filesystem.
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The root filesystem must contain the tools and files that are essential to startup the system and be able to repair it.

item.question: Which command will show the last 10 lines of a file by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
On a Debian system which runlevels represent multi-user?
Select all that apply?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands enables write access to the file /usr/share/doc/lpi303/test for users who belong to the group of the file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to get the fourth line from a file.
Which of the following commands would you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the above piece of code that uses tabs to indent lines.
Which command will easily convert the tabs to 8 spaces?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You started an application (myapp) in the foreground.
How do you push this running application into the background without restarting the application?
item.choice: It is not possible without restarting the application.
item.hint: An application running in the foreground is able to receive signals using key combinations through a terminal. An application running in the background is not.

item.question:
When partitioning a disk with more than 1024 cylinders, which of the following could affect the systems ability to boot?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The location of the Master Boot Record
Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.correct_answer: Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.hint: This problem occured years ago on systems where the BIOS did not support disks with more then 1024 cylinders. Nowadays you will probably never encounter this problem although Linux is occasionally used on old systems someone has lying around.

item.question: Which of the following commands will replace all lower case characters with upper case characters?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
During installation of the package atop you encountered an error.
Which command will display the package status?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Is it possible for a regular user to mount and unmount a filesystem?
item.choice: There is no way a regular user can do this, because it is a root privilege.
Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">user</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">allusers</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
Yes, any user can mount and unmount filesystems.
item.correct_answer: Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">user</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands makes <font face="monospace">/tmp/myfile</font> readable by everyone but readable/executable only by its owner?
item.hint: If you look at the answers you should see that the exhibit is bogus and you should be able to answer the question without it. Note that the answers cover two commands (i.e. <font face="monospace">chmod</font> and <font face="monospace">chown</font>). If you are in a hurry you might not notice this.

item.question:
Which of the following commandlines can you use in a BASH shell to make sure the command started in the shell uses the configuration-file top.conf.
Select two.
item.hint: You will need to provide exactly two correct answers. Note that defining a variable and using a variable requires a different syntax. Also note that the question mentions commands started in the shell should be able to read the variable. Hence, the shell should pass the variable to its childs.

item.question: Where would you add a library path if the library is currently located in your homedirectory and only temporarily used?
item.choice: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
Add it to <font face="monospace">/etc/modprob.conf</font> and run <font face="monospace">ldconfig</font> afterwards to update the cache-file
Call the system administrator and have her add it to the correct location
item.correct_answer: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
The ________ directory is world writable.
Therefore it should be on a separate partition (filesystem) to prevent users from filling up the root-filesystem.
item.hint: Questions regarding the directory structure on Linux always assume the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard. Note that, if it is not stated explicitly your safest bet is to provide the full pathname to the directory as well.

item.question:
You installed a new set of shared libraries in /usr/local/mynewlib.
You run the command ldconfig.
However, running the application still causes problems, complaining it cannot find the shared libraries.
What is most likely the cause of this?
item.choice: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
When you install new libraries, you need to recompile or re-install the application.
You forgot to add the library path to the <font face="monospace">PATH</font> variable.
You forgot to reboot the system (the libraries are discovered at kernel initialization).
item.correct_answer: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: On an ext3 partition, what portion of the datablocks on the filesystem is reserved for the root user by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You enter a command (mycmd) in bash and want to redirect both standard output and standard error output to one file (mylog).
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: This is a tricky question. If you know your I/O redirection rules you will probably find one correct answer quickly. But there are actually two correct answers. Before the shell will fork and execute the command it will have rewritten the commandline and removed all special characters and words from the commandline. So the order may not be that important.

item.question: Which command can be used to make init reload its configuration file?
item.hint: Although nowadays there are multiple versions of init used (e.g. <font face="monospace">systemd</font>, <font face="monospace">upstart</font>), if the question does not state a particular version explicitly assume the question is about the System V init system.

item.question:
You want to use vi-like editing commands at the bash command line editor.
However, the default bash settings enable emacs-like keystrokes.
How do you enable bash to recognize vi-like keystrokes?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Assume your current working directory is ~ and you wish to copy the files from the homedirectory of user guru1 to the directory temp in your homedirectory.
Which of the following commands will accomplish this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands gets its input from <font face="monospace">file1</font>, writes its output to <font face="monospace">file2</font> and writes errormessages to <font face="monospace">file3</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: How would you set the sticky bit on a directory?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which Linux command is used to repair corrupted filesystems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You plugged in a USB DVDROM drive. The dmesg command told you it was detected as device /dev/sr0.
There is no fstab-entry for this device in /etc/fstab.
Which of the following commands can you use to mount the media in that drive to the (existing) directory /mnt/dvdrom?
item.hint: Many questions require you to know which options a command accepts and in which order. This can be very hard to memorize and you may find it difficult to choose between two answers that only differ in the order of their arguments. Fortunately, you can always come back to this question later on. Sometimes another question might give you a clue for a previous question.

item.question:
You execute the above command.
You now want to know which echo command was executed.
Which command is best fit for the job?
item.hint: When it is not stated explicitly which shell is used assume the Bash shell.

item.question: With Xorg 7.0, what is the name of the configuration file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to repeat the 13th command in your history.
How would you do this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.exhibit:
$ ls -l /tmp/test
total 4
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 6 2010-10-28 12:56 desiree -> potato
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 7 2010-10-28 12:57 fries -> desiree
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 10 2010-10-28 12:48 potato
$ rm desiree
item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
What would best describe the rm command at the end?
item.choice: It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font> and the contents of the file potato
It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font> as well as the symbolic link <font face="monospace">fries</font>
It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font>
It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font> and relink the symbolic link <font face="monospace">fries</font> to <font face="monospace">potato</font>
item.correct_answer: It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font>
item.hint: Symbolic links are files that contain a directory path and filename to the file they are pointing to.

item.question:
On a Red Hat 5 system, which of the following commands can you use to update the package bind to the latest available version?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which command would find only the program file atop, it's configuration files, it's manual pages, and source files?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The question is not about any file that contains the text <font face="monospace">atop</font> but specific kind of files that belong to the program <font face="monospace">atop</font>.

item.question: Which of the following commands will give you the usernames of all users that are running a proces at this moment:
item.hint: The question only requires you to provide the usernames. All other information provided by <font face="monospace">ps</font> may be discarded.

item.question:
You are curious to which RPM-package the file /sbin/fdisk belongs.
Which command do you use to find out?
item.hint: You usually get multiple questions about the same command. Going back and forth to the questions covering the same command may provide you with clues to answer the questions correctly.

item.exhibit:
/bin/ls: ELF 32-bit LSB executable, Intel 80386, version 1
(SYSV), for GNU/Linux 2.6.9, dynamically linked (uses
shared libs), for GNU/Linux 2.6.9, stripped
item.question: Which command will produce the above output?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What would the file <font face="monospace">/etc/updatedb.conf</font> allow you to do?
item.choice: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database
Specify the time at wich the locate-database should be updated
Specify which users are allowed to use the <font face="monospace">locate</font> command
item.correct_answer: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following statements about symbolic links is true?
item.choice: A symbolic link can be recognized by filetype l as being the most-left character in the output of ls -l.
It is not possible to point a symbolic link to a directory in another filesystem.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
The command <font face="monospace">find / -type s</font> only displays symbolic links.
A symbolic link does not have its own inode-number.
item.correct_answer: It is not possible to point a symbolic link to a directory in another filesystem.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want to repeat the last command that began with the letters 'mo'. How would you do this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
A user calls claiming she gets an error message saying there is no space left on the device when creating a new file.
Which command would you use to verify the problem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
The user guru1 complains that he cannot access his homedirectory.
Given the directory /home/guru1 has the above permissions.
Which of the following commands would fix this problem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Considering the command <font face="monospace">dpkg</font> which of the following options are correct?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which command would allow you to remove a file on a filesystem without actually mounting it?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The kernelfile vmlinuz-2.6.18 is in the ________ directory.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer. Note that the question does not explicitly state you should provide the absolute path as well. Your safest bet is to provide the absolute path.

item.question:
You want to move everything within directory /home/guru1 to the empty directory /home/guru2.
Which of the following commands would be best to use?
(note: there are no hidden files in /home/guru1)
item.hint: You need to move the contents of <font face="monospace">/home/guru1</font> and not the directory itself.

item.question: What is the mountpoint of the first swap partition?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: How can you disable only the group quota in <font face="monospace">/extra</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You issue the above command with root-privileges.
What will happen to your system?
item.choice: Your system will make eating sounds (yum, yum)
Your debian system will be upgraded to the new stable version
Your redhat system will be upgraded to the new release version
Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.correct_answer: Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.hint: Usually you use <font face="monospace">yum upgrade</font> to upgrade the system to a new version but this requires more actions than are mentioned in the question.

item.question:
On a system that has the above uptime.
Which command is best used to print out system boot messages?
item.hint: The kernel keeps the messages in a buffer in memory. This buffer is limited and when full messages are removed using a first in first out algorithm.

item.question: You have downloaded an archive called <font face="monospace">atop.tgz</font>. Which command could you use to verify the checksum of the file?
item.hint: Although the question does not mention the actual checksum used on the file you should be able to answer the question correctly by eliminating all non-existing commands on a standard Linux system.

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to examine kernel bootup messages after boot time?
item.hint: Some questions allow multiple answers. Sometimes the question will state how many correct answers are required, in this case not. If you do not know the answer immediately the best strategy is eliminating the answers you know are wrong and select the best answer from the ones that are left. Sometimes another question might give you a clue for a previous question. You can always come back to this question later on.

item.exhibit:
# jobs -l
[1] Running firefox &
[2]- Stopped atop
[3]+ Stopped vi
item.question: Given the above exhibit, which command could you use to terminate the application 'vi'?
item.hint: Sometimes the correct answer does not fit the question exactly. However, eliminating the wrong answers should lead to the correct answer.
